key: Mothers Receiving Prenatal Care During First Trimester
Children with Elevated Lead Blood Levels
description: According to the CDC, no level of lead in the blood is safe for children. An elevated blood level is 10 or more micrograms of lead in a deciliter (?g/dL) of blood.

key: Annual Years of Potential Life Lost
description: Years of potential life lost (YPLL) is a measure of premature mortality, recognizing that death at a younger age implies a greater loss of productive years than death in old age. YPLL is calculated for each person dying before age 75 by subtracting the age at death from 75, and then summed within each community area. A higher YPLL indicates more premature death.

Low Income Student Enrollment in Chicago Public Schools

description: The Hardship Index is a composite score reflecting hardship in the community (higher values indicate greater hardship). It incorporates unemployment, dependency (minors and elderly), education, per capita income, crowded housing, and poverty. See technical notes for details.
source: Presence Health, based on American Community Survey

description: The Race-Ethnicity Diversity Index measures the probability that any two residents of an area belong to the same race and ethnicity. A score of 0 represents a perfectly homogenous community; the higher the score, the more diverse the area. The highest possible score is 0.875, not 1. The index includes Non-Hispanic White, Non-Hispanic Black, Hispanic/Latino, Asian, American Indian/Alaskan, Pacific Islander/Hawaiian, other, and two or more races.
source: Presence Health, based on American Community Survey, Table B03002

description: The Gini index measures how much the distribution of income deviates from a fully equal distribution. A value of 0 represents perfect equality (every household has the same income), and a value of 100 represents perfect inequality (one household has all the income). The corresponding Gini index for the United States as a whole is 0.476.

key: Children with high blood lead levels, 2013
description: Percent of children tested. Children with blood lead levels of 6 micrograms/dL or greater. According to the CDC, no level of lead in the blood is safe for children, but special attention should be paid when levels are above 5 micrograms/dL.
source: Chicago Department of Public Health via the Chicago Tribune

key: Children with high blood lead levels, 2009-2013
description: Percent of children tested. Children with blood lead levels of 6 micrograms/dL or greater. According to the CDC, no level of lead in the blood is safe for children, but special attention should be paid when levels are above 5 micrograms/dL.
source: Chicago Department of Public Health via the Chicago Tribune

key: Children with high blood lead levels, 1995-1999
description: Percent of children tested. Children with blood lead levels of 6 micrograms/dL or greater. According to the CDC, no level of lead in the blood is safe for children, but special attention should be paid when levels are above 5 micrograms/dL.
source: Chicago Department of Public Health via the Chicago Tribune

description: The environmental health hazard exposure index summarizes potential exposure to harmful toxins at a neighborhood level, as a linear combination of standardized EPA estimates of air quality carcinogenic, respiratory, and neurological hazards. Values range from 0 to 100 and are national percentile ranks. The higher the index value, the less exposure to toxins harmful to human health. Therefore, the higher the value, the better the environmental quality of a neighborhood.
source: Department of Housing and Urban Development / National Air Toxics Assessment

description: Ratio of total respiratory hazard from all sources and all air pollutants to the level of pollutants at which no adverse outcomes are expected. An index value above 1 indicates an added respiratory hazard from air pollutants, and higher index values indicate increased hazard. However, no specific likelihood of adverse effects is implied by index values above 1, and the index should not be interpreted as proportional to risk. Two areas with the same hazard index could have very different air pollution profiles and risks of respiratory outcomes, depending on the relative concentrations of pollutants in the air and how they interact.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: Index of respiratory hazard from mobile gasoline emitters like cars and trucks, relative to the level of gasoline-based pollutants at which no adverse outcomes are expected. An index value above 1 indicates an added respiratory hazard, and higher index values indicate increased hazard. However, no specific likelihood of adverse effects is implied by index values above 1, and the index should not be interpreted as proportional to risk. Values below 1 generally indicate no added respiratory risk from mobile gasoline emitters.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: Index of respiratory hazard from mobile diesel emitters like cars and trucks, relative to the level of gasoline-based pollutants at which no adverse outcomes are expected. An index value above 1 indicates an added respiratory hazard, and higher index values indicate increased hazard. However, no specific likelihood of adverse effects is implied by index values above 1, and the index should not be interpreted as proportional to risk. Values below 1 generally indicate no added respiratory risk from mobile diesel emitters.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: The added number of cancer cases attributable to outdoor air pollutants, per million residents, per year. For instance, a value of 1 indicates that, on average, every resident of this area has a 1 in 1 million chance of contracting cancer each year due to environmental pollutants in concentrations above generally safe levels. Note that this is the added risk due to high concentrations of pollutants, not the total risk due to environmental pollutants.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: Estimated concentration in outdoor air. The Integrated Risk Information System sets the reference concentration (beyond which there may be negative health effects) at 2 ug/m3. Actual exposure may be somewhat less than ambient concentration.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: Estimated concentration in outdoor air. The Integrated Risk Information System sets the reference concentration (beyond which there may be negative health effects) at 9 ug/m3. Actual exposure may be somewhat less than ambient concentration.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: Estimated concentration in outdoor air. The Integrated Risk Information System sets the reference concentration (beyond which there may be negative health effects) at 0.02 ug/m3. Actual exposure may be somewhat less than ambient concentration.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: Estimated concentration in outdoor air. The Integrated Risk Information System sets the reference concentration (beyond which there may be negative health effects) at 30 ug/m3. Actual exposure may be somewhat less than ambient concentration.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: Estimated concentration in outdoor air. The Integrated Risk Information System sets the reference concentration (beyond which there may be negative health effects) at 0.8 ug/m3. Actual exposure may be somewhat less than ambient concentration.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: Estimated concentration in outdoor air of particulate matter from diesel. The Integrated Risk Information System sets the reference concentration (beyond which there may be negative health effects) at 5 ug/m3. Actual exposure may be somewhat less than ambient concentration.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: Estimated concentration in outdoor air. The Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry sets the reference concentration (beyond which there may be negative health effects) at 9.8 ug/m3. Actual exposure may be somewhat less than ambient concentration.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: Estimated concentration in outdoor air. The Integrated Risk Information System sets the reference concentration (beyond which there may be negative health effects) at 3 ug/m3. Actual exposure may be somewhat less than ambient concentration.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: Estimated concentration in outdoor air. The Integrated Risk Information System sets the reference concentration (beyond which there may be negative health effects) at 2 ug/m3. Actual exposure may be somewhat less than ambient concentration.
source: Environmental Protection Agency, National Air Toxics Assessment

description: A measure of proximity to heavy traffic, defined as the average annual daily traffic at major roads within 500 meters, divided by distance in meters. Higher values indicate higher exposure to heavy traffic.
source: Environmental Protection Agency EJSCREEN, US DOT

description: A measure of proximity to water polluters, defined as the count of National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System major facilities within 5km (or the closest one further than 5km), each divided by distance in km. Higher values indicate closer proximity to major sites.

A measure of proximity to Superfund (toxic waste) sites, defined as the count of proposed and listed National Priorities List sites within 5km (or the closest one further than 5km), each divided by distance in km. Higher values indicate closer proximity to major sites.

key: Proximity to potential chemical accident sites
description: A measure of proximity to potential chemical accidents, defined as the count of proposed and listed RMP (potential chemical accident management plan) sites within 5km (or the closest one further than 5km), each divided by distance in km. Higher values indicate closer proximity to major sites.

key: Proximity to hazardous waste management sites
description: A measure of proximity to hazardous waste management sites, defined as the count of hazardous waste Treatment, Storage, and Disposal Facilities within 5km (or the closest one further than 5km), each divided by distance in km. Higher values indicate closer proximity to major sites.
Summer seasonal daily average, maximum 8-hour concentration in air.
Annual average. PM 2.5, or particulate matter smaller than 2.5 microns in diameter, is one of the most dangerous pollutants because the particles can penetrate deep into the alveoli of the lungs.

Index of vulnerable populations, a composite of low-income, minority, age <5, age 65+, below high school education, and linguistically isolated individuals. The index is constructed using national statistics as benchmarks, and thus represents the degree to which this area has a higher proportion of vulnerable residents than the nation as a whole. Reported as a percentile rank within Illinois, where 0 = lowest percentage of vulnerable residents, and 100 = highest percentage of vulnerable residents.

Index of exposure to diesel particulate matter, weighted by vulnerability of the population (reported as a percentile within Illinois, where 0 = lowest exposure, and 100 = highest vulnerability). Weighting by the vulnerability of residents can provide a better estimate of the disproportionate impact of environmental hazards.

Index of exposure to cancer-causing air pollutants, weighted by vulnerability of the population (reported as a percentile within Illinois, where 0 = lowest exposure, and 100 = highest vulnerability). Weighting by the vulnerability of residents can provide a better estimate of the disproportionate impact of environmental hazards.

Index of exposure to outdoor respiratory hazards, weighted by vulnerability of the population (reported as a percentile within Illinois, where 0 = lowest exposure, and 100 = highest vulnerability). Weighting by the vulnerability of residents can provide a better estimate of the disproportionate impact of environmental hazards.

Index of exposure to traffic, weighted by vulnerability of the population (reported as a percentile within Illinois, where 0 = lowest exposure, and 100 = highest vulnerability). Weighting by the vulnerability of residents can provide a better estimate of the disproportionate impact of environmental hazards.

Index of exposure to housing built before 1960 and at risk of containing lead, weighted by vulnerability of the population (reported as a percentile within Illinois, where 0 = lowest exposure, and 100 = highest vulnerability). Weighting by the vulnerability of residents can provide a better estimate of the disproportionate impact of environmental hazards.

Index of exposure to major water polluting sites, weighted by vulnerability of the population (reported as a percentile within Illinois, where 0 = lowest exposure, and 100 = highest vulnerability). Weighting by the vulnerability of residents can provide a better estimate of the disproportionate impact of environmental hazards.

Index of exposure to Superfund toxic waste sites, weighted by vulnerability of the population (reported as a percentile within Illinois, where 0 = lowest exposure, and 100 = highest vulnerability). Weighting by the vulnerability of residents can provide a better estimate of the disproportionate impact of environmental hazards.

key: Potential Chemical Accidents Environmental Justice Index
description: Index of exposure to potential chemical accident sites, weighted by vulnerability of the population (reported as a percentile within Illinois, where 0 = lowest exposure, and 100 = highest vulnerability). Weighting by the vulnerability of residents can provide a better estimate of the disproportionate impact of environmental hazards.

Index of exposure to hazardous waste treatment and disposal sites, weighted by vulnerability of the population (reported as a percentile within Illinois, where 0 = lowest exposure, and 100 = highest vulnerability). Weighting by the vulnerability of residents can provide a better estimate of the disproportionate impact of environmental hazards.

Index of exposure to ozone, weighted by vulnerability of the population (reported as a percentile within Illinois, where 0 = lowest exposure, and 100 = highest vulnerability). Weighting by the vulnerability of residents can provide a better estimate of the disproportionate impact of environmental hazards.

Index of exposure to PM 2.5, weighted by vulnerability of the population (reported as a percentile within Illinois, where 0 = lowest exposure, and 100 = highest vulnerability). Weighting by the vulnerability of residents can provide a better estimate of the disproportionate impact of environmental hazards.

The Child Opportunity Index evaluates the neighborhood-based opportunities that influence a child's health and development. The index is a z-score comparing all ZIP codes within a metropolitan area; higher values indicate better opportunity. The Overall Childhood Opportunity Index is a composite of the Educational, Health and Environmental, and Social and Economic sub-indices.
source: Brandeis University and the Kirwan Institute as modified and calculated by the Chicago Department of Public Health Office of Epidemiology. Methodology at http://www.diversitydatakids.org/files/CHILDOI/DOCS/DDK_KIRWAN_CHILDOI_OVERVIEW.pdf

description: The Child Opportunity Index evaluates the neighborhood-based opportunities that influence a child's health and development. The index is a z-score comparing all ZIP codes within a metropolitan area; higher values indicate better opportunity. The Educational Opportunity sub-index includes: adult educational attainment, student poverty rate, reading proficiency rate, math proficiency rate, early childhood education neighborhood participation patterns, high school graduation rate, proximity to high-quality early childhood education centers, and proximity to early childhood education centers of any type.
source: Brandeis University and the Kirwan Institute as modified and calculated by the Chicago Department of Public Health Office of Epidemiology. Methodology at http://www.diversitydatakids.org/files/CHILDOI/DOCS/DDK_KIRWAN_CHILDOI_OVERVIEW.pdf

description: The Child Opportunity Index evaluates the neighborhood-based opportunities that influence a child's health and development. The index is a z-score comparing all ZIP codes within a metropolitan area; higher values indicate better opportunity. The Health and Environmental Opportunity sub-index includes: retail healthy food index, proximity to toxic waste release sites, volume of nearby toxic release, proximity to parks and open spaces, housing vacancy rates, and proximity to health care facilities.
source: Brandeis University and the Kirwan Institute as modified and calculated by the Chicago Department of Public Health Office of Epidemiology. Methodology at http://www.diversitydatakids.org/files/CHILDOI/DOCS/DDK_KIRWAN_CHILDOI_OVERVIEW.pdf

description: The Child Opportunity Index evaluates the neighborhood-based opportunities that influence a child's health and development. The index is a z-score comparing all ZIP codes within a metropolitan area; higher values indicate better opportunity. The Social and Economic Opportunity sub-index includes: neighborhood foreclosure rate, poverty rate, unemployment rate, public assistance rate, and proximity to employment.
source: Brandeis University and the Kirwan Institute as modified and calculated by the Chicago Department of Public Health Office of Epidemiology. Methodology at http://www.diversitydatakids.org/files/CHILDOI/DOCS/DDK_KIRWAN_CHILDOI_OVERVIEW.pdf

description: Principal diagnosis. U.S. Postal Service ZIP Codes are designed to meet the day-to-day operational needs of the U.S. Postal Service and tend to change more frequently than every ten years. To account for this instability, as well as the emergence of new ZIP codes over the course of the decade and low population estimates in certain ZIP codes (i.e., less than 20,000 residents), some zip codes are combined.  1)The total number of hospitalizations and total population of ZIP codes 60707, 60638, and 60827 were included, regardless of whether the hospitalized individual resided within the Chicago city limits; 2) 60610 and 60654 are combined; 3) 60707 and 60635 are combined; 4) 60622 and 60642 are combined; 5) 60606, 60607, and 60661 are combined; 6) 60601, 60602, 60603, 60604, 60605, and 60611 are combined; 7) 60827 and 60633 are combined.

key: Annual years of potential life lost
description: Years of potential life lost (YPLL) is a measure of premature mortality, recognizing that death at a younger age implies a greater loss of productive years than death in old age. YPLL is calculated for each person dying before age 75 by subtracting the age at death from 75, and then summed within each ZIP code. A higher YPLL indicates more premature death.
source: Illinois Department of Public Health, 2013 mortality data, as analyzed by the Chicago Department of Public Health, Office of Epidemiology
